question: Hey! Do you sell crack? It's cool. I'm only a cop on TV. Is this crack? Do you know how to do it? Yes, hello. I'm having a medical situation. Yes. Okay. I don't have a belly button. I do not have a belly button where I should, on my belly. And I'm concerned, because I don't know if that's... Can a person live without a belly button? Because if you think about it, you're born with one. So if you don't have one, you're unborn and it's really hazy whether you're alive or not. I guess I'm wondering No, no. I'm totally sober. No, I don't think I need an ambulance. I don't seem to be dying any faster than usual. But I should probably go to the hospital, don't you think? Yeah, I should.
answer: La la la la la. Like you've never done worse. Okay, yes. He totalled a car. But it was an environmentally friendly car. Why doesn't that get reported? Please! He was heartbroken, betrayed. You say you understand but you don't. You can't. You're like a big giant Vulcan. He's coming. I'll call you later.

question: being escorted through glass doors by a polo-shirted PAROLE OFFICER. Margaret moves to intercept them, offering a hand.
answer: Hi. Margaret. I work for Lola.

question: Gary.
answer: I know. We need to go out the back.

question: Are there reporters out front?
answer: A few. Not Hugh Grant level. More like Robert Downey, Jr. when he broke into that family's house and slept in the kid's bed like Goldilocks. "This bed is just right." I handled episodes two through four for Robert. This sort of thing is my specialty.

question: What is?
answer: Famous fuck-ups. Don't worry. Mama's gonna take good care of you.

question: Hello? Yes. Yes. The weather in Toledo is rainy. Nine dogs ran through the field. The koala sits in the tree.
answer: It's computer voice recognition. The system can call you any time day or night. If you don't answer within five rings, the police come and haul your ass off.

question: What if I'm not here?
answer: That's why it's called house arrest. You stay inside your house. He can take direction, I promise. Okay, just so it's said, this house is flammable.

question: I didn't mean to burn down my house.
answer: Yeah, I didn't mean to eat my way into a ten-year shame spiral, but I did, and it's healthier to acknowledge it. This flammable house belongs to one of Lola's other fabulous clients, who is currently shooting a pilot in Toronto.

question: Actor?
answer: Writer. So for the next six weeks, su casa es su casa. I say, feel free to wear his clothes. He'll probably get a sick thrill of out it. The gays.

question: He has dogs?
answer: They're away at summer camp. Now, try the bed.

question: It's fine.
Sure.
answer: Look, Gary, I know this has been crazy and stressful. I want you to feel safe. And comfortable.

question: I do.
answer: I'm a fan of yours, you know. Your number-one fan. But if you fuck this up, I will smash your ankles with a sledge hammer. That wouldn't be comfortable for either of us.

question: I'll be coming by twice a day to check up on you. I'm the only person who should be coming by. No buddies, no pals, no heroin dealers...
Yeah, crack is classy. And I'm not buying you porn. There's spray-per- view on cable.
answer: Good. I really wasn't concerned about my career, my family or my future. I just wanted to jack off.

question: Let me see your phone.
answer: C'mon! All my numbers are in that.

question: Dial ten digits at random. Whoever answers will be better than the people on this phone. You have my cell number. You have delivery menus. You're fine. Right?
answer: I guess. Once we get these samples back to the Crime Lab, we'll know who the real killer is. Is somebody there? Hello? Hello?! Yes. Yes. Nine leopards run through the jungle. I bought two cakes at the store. The house is haunted. There's a zeitgeist, or something.

question: Poltergeist, and no. Maybe they were rats. L.A. is teaming with rats. They live in the palm trees.
Okay. You know I'm a licensed psychotherapist.
No. I'm a publicist. My job is what other people think of you, not what you think of yourself. So pull your shit together. I am thisclose to getting Christine Walsh to do your piece in Parade.
Everyone hates Parade. But the people who watch "Crime Lab," they love their Marilyn Vos Savant. Give them a woman of indeterminate age who solves riddles and they are in hee-haw heaven.
One heartfelt act of contrition and maybe the showrunner won't kill off your character between seasons. I swear to God, if you go batshit on me...
I'm working on my putting, if you can believe it.
Okay. Maybe I was just looking for a way to meet my infamous neighbor. You see, I'm under house arrest, too.
I had sex with my husband.
Nine months later, I had Jaden. That's her over there.
She's sleeping for another... ...seventeen minutes. She keeps to a schedule.
She is.
answer: You're rich. Shouldn't you have a nanny from Ecuador?

question: I'm Canadian.
I can't work in the U.S. Plus, I want to maintain this air of moral superiority by doing everything myself.
Thanks. Listen, Jaden goes down again at 2:30. Maybe I could stop by.
answer: I'm pretty sure I'll be here.

question: It's a date.
Oh. I'm Sarah, by the way.
The best of all possible worlds.
Voltaire. Candide. Are you actually reading it?
Sorry I bailed. Jaden had a fever.
Housewarming gift.
The best part is, I can drink it. I pumped before I came.
answer: So did I. ... so it's kind of hard to prove that I only meant to burn my ex- girlfriend's stuff, and not the entire house.

question: Yeah. Fire's tricky that way.
answer: How about you? Any history of arson?

question: Strangely enough...
answer: I knew it! I could see that little spark.

question: It wasn't arson. Probably. Okay. When I was a little girl, our house caught on fire.

I'll never forget the look on my father's face as he gathered me up in his arms and raced through the burning building, out onto the pavement. I stood there shivering in my pajamas and watched the whole world go up in flames. And when it was all over, I said to myself, "Is that all there is to a fire?" Is that all there is? Is that all there is, is that all there is? If that's all there is my friends, then let's keep dancing. Let's break out the booze and have a ball. If that's all there is. Is that all there is, is that all there is? If that's all there is my friends, then let's keep dancing. Let's break out the booze and have a ball, If that's all there is. Then I fell in love with the most wonderful boy in the world. We would take long walks by the river or just sit for hours gazing into each other's eyes. We were so very much in love. Then one day he went away and I thought I'd die. But I didn't. And when I didn't, I said to myself, "Is that all there is to love?" Is that all there is? Is that all there is? If that's all there is my friends, then let's keep... I know what you're thinking. If that's the way she feels about it why doesn't she just end it all? I'm in no hurry for that final disappointment. I know just as well as I'm standing here talking to you, when that final moment comes and I'm breathing my last breath, I'll be saying to myself... I need to...
My shoes. Are here. Okay. Crap!
Goodnight. Hello. Yes. Yes. Two trains run through the forest. Jesus! You scared the shit out of... What?
I don't speak that. Sorry. I don't... I'm fine. I'll be fine. Where are your parents? Your mom, your dad. Where are they?
answer: Mom is at the car. Where you left her. Again, Gary has no idea what she's saying. You're lost.

question: Look, you need to go back, okay? You shouldn't be out here. It's not safe. Shit. Evening, officers.
answer: Once again, the idea of house arrest is you stay inside your house. Think of it like an electronic leash. Basically, if you ever go more than 100 feet from the base station... ...the cops come, they throw your ass in jail. If you ever try to take it off, the cops come and throw your ass in jail. And if they ever detect drugs or alcohol in your system...

question: ...the cops come and throw my ass in jail.
answer: No. I kick your ass. Then the cops come and throw your ass in jail.

question: Do I still have to answer the phone?
answer: No, I'll be doing that from now on. I'm moving into the guest room.

question: I don't need a babysitter.
answer: Despite all evidence to the contrary. Don't worry, I'm a cool roomie. Who do you think taught Affleck how to gamble? Let's never hear that again. Behold! The edge of your world. In the world. Out of the world. In the world. Out of the world. Look at me, I'm dancin'!

question: So the guy was like, "Do you know fencing?" And I say, of course. That's what it says on my headshot.
Always. So he says, "Foil or epi?"
I say, I'm about equal in both.
So he tosses me this fucking Conan sword and goes after me. I'm just swinging, trying to stay alive. But I end up cutting his ear.
Just a little. But I got the job.
answer: Wait. You were in Pirates of the Caribbean?

question: Yes. No. Not the movie, the ride. I was like, "Gar! Keep both hands inside the boat!"
Goodnight, you filthy whore.
I know. Whenever I see them, and I always feel like, damn...
answer: ...I was born at the wrong time.

question: Exactly.
Groceries.
How's Jaden?
answer: Boring. We haven't had nearly the grand old time you two have been having.

question: You've been watching.
answer: Well. I don't want to meddle in your affairs.

question: My affairs?
answer: Everyone needs affection. I get it.

question: I don't. Are you seriously jealous?
answer: The opposite. I just want to protect her.

question: From what?
answer: From you. Look at you. You date models. Actresses. Tennis players.

question: Yeah.
answer: On a scale of one to ten, you belong with the Nines. We both know you won't settle for less.

question: What are "the Nines?"
"Look for the Nines."
It's your handwriting.
Okay. All-ee-all-ee-all-come-free.
Nothing.
Nothing. I thought you were...forget it. Done. Sorry. Yhello? Hi. What?! I have to take this. Well, who thought it was a good idea letting Courtney into a pottery shop? I know who you are.
I know what you are. And if you come near him again...
answer: You'll what? What are you going to do, M... Sorry, what's he calling you?

question: Margaret.
Why can't you just leave him alone?
answer: Alone? He's an actor. If nobody's watching him, he doesn't really exist. And for the record, I'm not the one deceiving him. He's going to figure it out eventually. And when he does, who do you think he's gonna blame?

question: Goodnight.
Hi.
answer: Sorry for the psychotic episode. I'll blame it on hormones.

question: Okay.
answer: Are you alright? You look a little Beautiful Mind-ish.

question: How many times should the number nine come up? Probablistically?
You know what I mean.
How about every time? But they only show up when you look for them. Looking for them changes things.
answer: Some of these are prices. There's going to be a lot of nines when...

question: There is something wrong with the world.
answer: You have an eyelash on your... here... I can get you out of here. But you have to trust me.

question: You okay?
Oh.
The Nines?
Sort of hard to start there...
answer: Try. And don't tell me I'm imagining it. They're showing up everywhere, and I want to know why.

question: Best guess? They're your subconscious trying to remind you who you are.
Yes. It doesn't make a lot of sense of out context. Coffee?
answer: Why don't you drink coffee? You're always drinking tea.

question: Happy? You're not going to understand this yet, but we've known each other for like 25 years. One day when I was 12, you called me out of the blue. And we've been talking ever since.
On the phone. Usually.
answer: I never met you before I came here.

question: You, Gary, never met me. But you're not always... I can understand why you're a little confused.
Theories?
No.
No.
answer: Then I'm dead. This is Hell, or Purgatorium or something.

question: Okay, a purgatorium is where Romans vomited. But no. This is as real as anything can be.
Everything is what it is. But you're not who you think you are. God, no! Please, Gary, don't. You don't know what you're doing.
answer: What happens if I cross this line?

question: I don't know. But it's not good.

The only way we can afford to shoot the pilot is in Canada. It's really hard to think about leaving for six weeks. Action! Puggies! It's weird being back. It doesn't feel like my house anymore. At this stage, you have the script you wrote, and the film you shot, but you don't know how it's all going to come together. You just know how you want it to feel.
answer: I just don't know if you need the cold open. People want to get right to the story.

question: I invited Susan to see a rough cut because I trust her taste.
answer: Could we be more clear why Mary is so freaked out at that moment?

question: Wow. I thought it was pretty obvious. And dramatic.
answer: I know. But that's Roger's big thing this season. Never let the audience be confused.

question: So we're trying to squeeze in a wild line over this shot of Noelle.
How could you...
Yeah.
answer: Howkajew. It sounds like kosher drug paraphernalia. Like, come on Shmuley! Have a toke on the Howkajew.

question: I know. It's just for the test screening.
answer: They really think people won't get it?

question: The dumb people might not.
answer: I didn't think we were making the show for dumb people. Howkajew... How could you... How couldjew... I feel so dirty.

question: So you'll look at the cards?

Sometimes the numbers point things out that you don't want to admit to yourself. In this case, Melissa. Her overall scores were okay. But if you look at the people who scored the show highest, the one consistent dip was Melissa.
answer: She doesn't have a ton to do in the pilot. There's so much to set up, you don't get a lot of Melissa- time.

question: True. That's one of the challenges with a premise pilot.
answer: But the network still likes the show?

question: Of course. Roger is your biggest cheerleader.
Roger calls the shots.
answer: After he consults with the Higher Powers.

question: True.
They haven't seen it. They're watching all the pilots on Friday.
answer: Why are you focusing on Melissa?

question: Because she's the biggest concern.
answer: She's also the biggest star in the show.

question: No, you're the biggest star. Roger made a huge deal with you, and he went along with casting Melissa when that wasn't his instinct.
answer: Well, hooray for Roger. I don't understand what you want me to do.

question: Meet with someone.
Dahlia Salem. The network has a holding deal with her.
answer: Yes. And you put her in Gatin's pilot.

question: It's dead. It's dying. But the network loves Dahlia. So if she could jump over to your show...
answer: Replace Melissa and reshoot the pilot.

question: Roger would pay for it.
answer: So is this even about Melissa?

question: It's about getting your show on the air. That's all that matters in the end.
answer: I see why the network loves her. It's just, I wrote the part for Melissa. She's one of my best friends. And in my head, I only see Melissa for the role. Could Dahlia do it? Absolutely. It could work. I just don't know if I want it to work. When I get stressed out, I play videogames. It's my therapy. I can't have them on my own computer, because then I'd never write. So I come down to Koreatown. Videogames are better than real life. When you get stuck, you can always hit `reset.' Life needs a reset button.

question: If we're really going to replace Melissa, I want to hear it from Roger.
answer: Roger's on a flight to London. But I talked with him before he left. He said yes on Dahlia.

question: What does that mean?
Yes, replace Melissa?
answer: He wants your show on the air, starring Dahlia. I just got off the phone with her agents. They love it. She loves you.

question: What about Melissa?
answer: You want me to call her agents?

question: God no. I'll tell her.
answer: As long as he needs me, I know where I must be... In-between the pilot and the series, I'm trying to squeeze in a one-woman show. I've always been obsessed with nuns. They're sort of like God's fag-hags.

question: I think my house is haunted.
1926. Ever since I got back, I feel like there's someone else there. And then last night, I thought I heard something. A woman singing.
I guess. And then I saw something. I ran into someone.
It was a man. I think it was me.
answer: Your house is haunted by yourself?

question: Yeah.
No. No. The network wants to replace you.

And I'm letting them, because I really want the show on the air. I have all these characters inside my head, and they want to live. I'm the only way they can. This is the only way they can. I have five seasons mapped out, and though it sucks, either you go away, or the show goes. I had to make a decision, and that's the decision I made. I'm sorry.
Yes.
answer: I understand. It's not your fault. You're morally incapable of doing the right thing. Don't get me wrong. I think you do feel bad for me. But that's all you feel for me. You still see me as the fat girl you call on Friday night when a date falls through. Let's go to a movie! Let's go to Fubar! And if you meet a hot piece of ass, don't worry about Melissa, you can apologize tomorrow. Or don't! Same difference. It's not like we're actually friends.

question: I don't want to do this on camera.
answer: No, because you can't control it. Your little puppets are off their strings, running around. Saying things you didn't write. Reality terrifies you.

question: Reality.
The reality is, you would not be here without me. I gave you your first few roles. And your career is a result of that.
answer: God, thank you. Thank you for finally playing that card. I always knew you were holding onto it, the "I invented Melissa McCarthy card." Congratulations, you win. The game is over. Don't you ever pity me again.

question: Upfronts is the week each year when the networks present their fall schedule to advertisers.
answer: Sort of like, "Here's our new shit. Like it?" Upfronts is a complete oxymoron, because no one is remotely honest.

question: The schedule is a secret until it's announced, so everything is still in play.
answer: But hey! At least you're in New York! It's surreal being here. None of this is how I planned it. Hey you! Get on. Come join reality television. When did you get in? I just said surreal. Please. Call anytime. I don't sleep. Did something happen? So I just bumped into Dahlia Salem, star of my show... ... who tells me Gatin's show got picked up, so no, she won't be in my show, which makes me wonder, does my show even exist? No, I've left word with Roger. I've left word with Susan. It's like they've dropped off the face of the Earth.

question: Look, I'm sorry. But I'm kind of not. I want my show on the air. And I think it was shitty for you to go after Dahlia behind my back.
answer: I heard your show was gone.

question: I "heard" you fired Melissa McCarthy without having a backup. Why would they pick up your show when you don't have a star?
Yeah, in my show. We tested right before you. Our numbers were through the roof.
Really. Who's your exec?
I'm at the UTA party. Yeah. Did you hear about Ricky's assistant? She literally shat herself. No, I saw it.
answer: I will break your fucking finger.

question: I'll call you back. Roger wanted to talk to you personally.
They're only picking up two dramas.
You can go mid-season.
Wow. You think I deliberately sabotaged your show.
G., I'm on your side. Trust me, I'm the only one who is trying to protect you.
answer: All I want to know is why.

question: You want a motive?
This isn't "Crime Lab." No one got murdered.
answer: My show did. So tell me why.

question: I had to get you away from her. She was holding you back.
You had to give her up. C'mon, G. If she really mattered, you couldn't have betrayed her so easily.

What, you're the victim? The big Creator can't stand up to one little d-girl? It was your choice. I didn't make you do anything. I mean, do you have any principles? Do you believe in anything but your own ego?
Your dialogue used to be sharper. Maybe Gatins could do a polish. Is that all there is? Do you feel like a man? Because I'll tell you a secret. You're not.
answer: Look, I don't want to do this anymore. My show's not going to happen, so this show is over. Done. Gone. I`m not going to be your fucking puppet. I'm fine. Oh God.

question: I can understand why you're a little confused.
Theories?
No.
No.
answer: Then I'm dead. This is Hell, or Purgatorium or something.

question: Okay, a purgatorium is where Romans vomited. But no. This is as real as anything can be.
Everything is what it is. But you're not who you think you are.

You're a multi-dimensional being of vast, almost infinite power. You created this world on a whim, and decided to stick around to see how it turned out. You, this body you're in, is just one of your incarnations. Avatars. Call you what you will.
Technically, no. If God is a ten -- a theoretical ultimate, that-which- no-greater-can-be-imagined -- you're more of a nine.
Humans are sevens. Monkeys are sixes.

Koalas. They're telepathic. Plus, they control the weather. What's important is that you, you're the big cheese. El Supremo. You could destroy the world with a single thought. Don't, incidentally. Just file that away. But the truth is, you hold all the cards So you understand, I would have told you earlier, but I didn't...
Okay.
answer: I understand. But I don't believe you.

question: Noelle! Don't get too far ahead.
answer: No. You had ice cream at lunch.

question: Apparently frozen yogurt doesn't count.
answer: I'll make note. Did you hit it?

question: Shouldn't have to. I think we left the overhead light on.
Battery is dead. Least the starter is.
We call the service. That's all we can do.
answer: It's just the little battery that's dead, right? The big one is probably fine.

question: I guess.
answer: We can't jump it from one battery to the other? Cross-over somehow?

question: Who did you marry? MacGyver?
No. Do you?
answer: Yes! One bar. We're okay. Daddy's calling people to help us.

question: The minute you try to place a call, the bar goes away.
Okay, I'll keep trying, Mary. But it will keep happening.
answer: Well, what do you want to do?

question: I don't know.
answer: Maybe if you hold it up higher.

question: The problem is we're boxed in. It's a canyon. Where we turned off the main road, it was more open. And higher, too.
I can run that.
You okay with that?
answer: I don't think we have a choice, so, yeah. Go.

question: Daddy's going to get a truck to help us out. You take care of your mom, okay? I'll be right back. Excuse me! Hi! Hello? Excuse me. Do you have a cell phone?
answer: No, I don't. There's no service up here.

question: Yeah, I'm finding that out.
answer: You can usually get a signal up at the ranger station.

question: Okay...
answer: You follow the road. It's probably... I don't know. You have a car?

question: It's dead. That's why I need...

Yeah. Are you headed back to your car now? If you could give me a ride to a gas station, wherever... Oh. Hey. Look, I'm not some crazy Ted Bundy guy. I'm not going to rape you or kill you or anything. Of course, that's what Ted Bundy would say. Look, I'm a videogame designer. My wife is an editor. My daughter is four. They're waiting back at the car, and I want to get some help before it gets dark.
answer: I can call somebody when I get to town.

question: I believe you. I do. But you don't know where the car is. And the guy might not come. We can't be up here all night.
Don't be sorry. Just help me out here.
Hey!
Once I was sure you weren't following me. I'm sorry, it's just...
answer: You thought I was Ted Bundy.

question: Kinda.
Sierra. Weird that there's no cars. At all.
So, listen. I'm parked that way. It's not that far. If you want, I'll give you a ride to town.
Yeah. Make up some karma.
Okay, confession. I kind of recognized you.
I wasn't sure, but I think I saw a picture of you in some videogame magazine my boyfriend had. You're, like, the shit.
You're like the Quentin Tarantino of that world. A videogame God.
Fine.
answer: You seriously recognized me off of one photo?

question: I thought you were kinda hot. Considering.
Within the subset of videogame people.
I wasn't masturbating to your picture or anything.
You should be. I'm stingy with compliments.
Ex-boyfriend. And yes. Way too many. He used to play Evercrack back in the day, but yours, well, that was like...what's worse than crack?
Sure. He was this orc witch doctor guy.
Yeah. At one point he was spending like, 40 hours a week gathering "thunderleaf" or whatever. Then I was his mule, hauling it around because he ran out of space.
I was part of your world, and you didn't even know it.
So it's done. Finished. Decided.
I understand.
So you play a lot of characters at once?
You're not most people. You created the world. You know all the secret codes.
That's what you call it?
answer: That's when you have all the powers, and you can't be killed. It's fine when you're designing, but it's really boring to play. A game isn't fun unless there are rules.

question: And you make the rules.
answer: Yes I do. I mean, you want to give everyone freedom, but they can't handle it. Half your players are teenage boys, and it's like they're programmed to be destructive. They deliberately crash the world servers. They'd ruin everything just to prove they could.

question: Do you think I'm pretty?
Do you think I'm hot? On a purely physical level.
That's a rave.
answer: Well, I don't know why you're asking.

question: My ex-boyfriend, the orc, he says, "What I like about you is that you're not so hot that I'm afraid of losing you."
He's dead. I spiked his water bottle with a massive quantity of GHB. He hallucinated, went into convulsions and died.
answer: Remind me not to piss you off, Sarah.

question: Sierra.
Am I crazy, or is it getting hotter?
I have a wife. And a daughter. They're waiting for me.
Back at the car.
They're back...
Where's your car?
answer: There is no car. That was all a... "pretense," I guess. An excuse to get you alone. Dizzy, huh? It's probably just the GHB. In the water.

question: Noelle! Noelle!
answer: She's here. I didn't forget you guys.

question: Everything okay?
You need to go, don't you?
How long? Forever? Every day, you'd know what you were missing. What happens? If you go.
answer: Worst-case scenario? Spontaneous disintegration into a fiery void. Oblivio accebit. The end of everything.

question: That's all?
answer: That probably wouldn't happen. The basic structure of the universe should hold. I guess I'm just worried about the human factor. You guys kill each other a lot.

question: In fairness, that's usually in your name. Plus we've gotten much more efficient at it.
answer: I like this world. I like my life, here, with you and Noelle...

question: But it's not real. I'm not really your wife, you're not really my husband. On some level, it's all pretend.
answer: It's not pretend. There's a reason you were there, in every version. You were my sister, my wife, my best friend...

question: That's a little creepy.
answer: I wanted you close. In one version, I even told you. I warned you that some day they might come for me, and...

question: ...You'd have to leave. How many versions were there?
answer: Ninety. This is the last one.

question: Wow.
answer: I've destroyed billions of people with a thought. Obliterated them. And you'd like to think it's painless...

question: Stop. You don't have to explain, or apologize. Everything that is, is because of you. If that's all, that's enough. So.
Guess you don't really need to pack anything.
You're great. It's been a pleasure.
Love you, too. Ya big lug.
